DOC.HEADLINE: FDA ALLOWS LABELS FOR MILK FROM COWS NOT GIVEN HORMONE
DOC.TEXT: Stores and dairies can label milk as coming from cows not treated with a controversial new hormone , but the labels can ' t suggest the milk is any safer than that from treated animals , the government said Monday . In guidelines to be published today , the Food and Drug Administration said companies may label milk , ice_cream and other dairy_products as coming from " cows not treated with " recombinant bovine somatotropin . But the label also would have to carry a statement like , " No significant difference has been shown between milk derived from rbST-treated and non-rbST-treated cows , " the agency said . The genetically engineered version of the naturally occurring hormone went_on the market Friday . The agency said labels could not carry the claim that milk is " bST-free " because the hormone occurs naturally in milk .
